text: So, so the first, the first thing we need to think about is, well, what are all the beings that are relevant to ethics And so we, when we see something like this, so here's a kind of Oscar winning performance here This little squirrel knows exactly what's going on She's going to put the thing on the neck Ah, look, it's had a terrible accident It's even going to look to see if the humans are watching to make sure that, see, are you guys looking Look, I've had a terrible accident And so when we see something like this, it's very obvious that this is something that has intelligence, that this is something that has preferences, that it has a theory of Mind And so that we, you know, that we have to be We have to be kind to things like this And it's obvious to us because it functions on the same scale of space and time, it operates in the same space as we do in three dimensional space It has somewhat similar goals to us in terms of survival and physiological integrity and so on
content_summary: The speaker discusses the intelligence and behavioral complexity of animals, using a squirrel as an example. The speaker emphasizes the ethical considerations necessary when dealing with intelligent beings that have preferences and a theory of mind.
